subject: Re: [junit] Re:How to use JUnit return String[]
msgSnippet: ... Not true.  Use is not the only tool for knowing or learning. Communication is another one.  And since Vladimir s library, for example, is talked about so
messageBody:
On Tue, 2004-03-23 at 20:47, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Jason Rogers wrote:
>
> > On Tue, 2004-03-23 at 17:12, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > > Jason Rogers wrote:
> > >
> > > > Not to play down Vladimir's JUnit-Addons, but if you want to test
> > arrays
> > > > it is simple enough to do the following given arrays a1 and a2:
> > > >
> > > > assertEquals(Arrays.asList(a1), Arrays.asList(a2));
> > > >
> > > > This will catch a great percentage of the equality tests you need.
> > >
> > > Yes, but why duplicate? Extract a method that reveals intent. Vladimir
> > > already did it, so let's use it.
> >
> > Yes, but you may not want to install a whole library for one method. :)
> > If that's all you want out of it, why use it.
>
> Today, you use one method. Tomorrow, you find out he has all this cool
> stuff and you start using more. If you never grab it, you'll never know,
> and you'll never learn.

Not true. Use is not the only tool for knowing or learning.
Communication is another one. And since Vladimir's library, for
example, is talked about so much on this list others will get the hint
and take a look at it. Word-of-mouth is generally a key motivator.
FWIW: I have Vlad's library in use in more than 3 projects currently.

>
> > Make your own testcase
> > that has that method in it, descend from that, and call it a day. The
> > method reveals intent and you don't have more classes hanging around
> > that you don't use.
>
> That's another way to do it, sure.
>
> > Granted, Vladimir's library isn't that large, but
> > it is another library to have to be concerned about when it comes to
> > versioning, updating, build time, etc.
>
> Agreed. That is a consideration. Still, why succumb to NIH syndrome?

Because we don't all live and work in a culture where we are free to
change everything. We keep squeaking and perhaps we'll get some oil, or
perhaps "The Company" will buy a new tire, at which point you just start
all over again. It's a wonderful cycle, actually, it drives out the
boredom. :)

--
Jason Rogers

"Where there is no vision, the people perish..."
Bible, Proverbs 29:18
